intro: Quercus baloot, commonly known as the Persian oak, is a deciduous tree native to the mountainous regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It belongs to the Fagaceae family, which includes oaks, beeches, and chestnuts. The tree is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn yellow in autumn, and its acorn-like fruits that are an important food source for various wildlife. Quercus baloot typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has a dense, rounded canopy. It is well adapted to dry and semi-arid climates, making it a hardy and resilient species in its native habitat.
